Dublin : printed for the Author, and sold by Booksellers, 1772.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="591" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Justice and policy, an essay on the increasing growth and enormities of our great cities : shewing the breaches thereby occasioned in the constitution, with a method to repair them, and, through the means of morality and industry, to place it upon a more firm basis, by the bands of union, that Britain may become the Asylum of Worth, and the Empire, with the commerce of it, justly established, instead of exchanging religion for trade : also, consideration upon the state of Ireland, with a proposal for the relief of it, and a scheme for its benefit, by employing the poor universally, together with reflections on police in general, and on the exportation of provisions from Ireland in particular : to which is added, thoughts on conquests, trade, and military colonies, &c. &c., divided into seven chapters : addressed to a noble peer / by a Freeholder in Ireland, and a Stockholder in England</subfield><subfield code="c">2334609</subfield><subfield code="t">BOOK</subfield><subfield code="n">DA947.Z9A56 v.3 c.1</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="949" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">DA947.Z9A56 v.3</subfield><subfield code="w">LC</subfield><subfield code="c">1</subfield><subfield code="i">000047519305</subfield><subfield code="m">UP-SPECCOL</subfield><subfield code="k">RARE-BOOK</subfield><subfield code="l">RARE-BOOK</subfield><subfield code="r">Y</subfield><subfield code="s">Y</subfield><subfield code="t">BOOK</subfield><subfield code="x">BW-CHILD</subfield></datafield></record>

And enriched with historical and explanatory notes. 5th ed. Dublin : W. Wilson, 1774. 17 pages ; 19 cm text txt rdacontent unmediated n rdamedia volume nc rdacarrier A satire, in verse, about an alleged amorous incident in Tahiti, based on material from John Hawkesworth's An account of the voyages ... Dublin : printed for the Author, and sold by Booksellers, 1772. Justice and policy, an essay on the increasing growth and enormities of our great cities : shewing the breaches thereby occasioned in the constitution, with a method to repair them, and, through the means of morality and industry, to place it upon a more firm basis, by the bands of union, that Britain may become the Asylum of Worth, and the Empire, with the commerce of it, justly established, instead of exchanging religion for trade : also, consideration upon the state of Ireland, with a proposal for the relief of it, and a scheme for its benefit, by employing the poor universally, together with reflections on police in general, and on the exportation of provisions from Ireland in particular : to which is added, thoughts on conquests, trade, and military colonies, &c. &c., divided into seven chapters : addressed to a noble peer / by a Freeholder in Ireland, and a Stockholder in England 2334609 BOOK DA947.Z9A56 v.3 c.1
